18.words: Okay. I think two things. So the first thing is when you kind of hear the words "child poverty" or "child hunger," you don't really think about the developed world. You're supposed to think about, "There are children dying in Africa," things like that, but I do think child poverty and child hunger in the US, but also in developed countries, is a really serious issue that a lot of people don't know about. So I actually appreciated that they took a specific look at that. I think the other thing I was thinking about, that was kind of interesting, was this idea that children who don't have food or they have food insecurity, get fed at school, because that's just something I've been paying attention to. In California, we have free lunch, but it was a whole thing, because everyone was like, "Oh. Why are we having free lunch for everybody?" Then, also we heard about Tim Waltz when he got nominated, and his whole thing, it wasn't his whole thing, but one of the biggest things he did was free lunch for Minnesota school children. And so, that was really interesting to me, because I think it's such an odd issue to be contentious about, but it just goes to show that people can argue about anything, so those are kind of the two things I was thinking about.

24.words: Well, I mean, I would say, I mean, do know what the con is, because I have seen it in discussions around these things, and the idea generally is that, I think you've mentioned this before, but it's the parents' fault for being poor, basically. I mean, also Martin mentioned that we don, we don't talk about poverty much in the developed world, but really we kind of do. I think I've seen it, maybe I've just seen it more than you have. We have two ways, generally, of categorizing poverty. One is, as Martin said, just kind of like, "Oh. It's somewhere out there, in Africa or wherever," whatever country is going through something right now, and so it's not really in our mind. The other one, the other way of thinking of poverty, is they deserve it, which is the two main narratives about poverty in the United States. People would be like, "I don't think the kid deserves it for being poor," but usually when it comes to the idea of pre-lunch and stuff, it's like, "Oh. The parents shouldn't be relying on things. 26.words: So I think it's a slow morning. It's taking me a little bit to process, but one of the things that I was kind of thinking about was, at least in my high school, I remember the switch to free lunch. I remember we used to pay for lunch, and they kind of had free or reduced lunch, and then everyone paid for lunch. I mean, didn't pay for lunch, like they passed a bill and it was free lunch. People were kind of like, "Oh. That's weird," but then it ended up being a really good thing, not only for the people who were food insecure, but then you had people who probably could afford food, but they were actually eating lunch for once in their lives. They weren't forgetting to eat, they weren't not packing food, because they realized, "Oh, it's there. Let me just go eat something," so it ended up being a net positive for everyone. I mean, other than just the baseline, "Yes, we should feed our kids," it was one of the most beneficial arguments to why we should provide this baseline. I think the other thing I was thinking about was, during COVID, when everything was shut down, schools became, at least in California, the place for people to get their food. They were still providing free lunch. They had drop-offs, they had places for people to come in and get their food, and I know because I had some people I know volunteer at the school, helping with distribution and helping make sure, and a lot of people actually came and grabbed food because this is what they relied on, and so I think that was really important. I have never really had a conversation with someone who is anti providing, not just kids free lunch, but I guess things like that, but what I do think is kind of funny is when this topic, like very recently with Tim Waltz, came in the mainstream, one of my favorite teachers I follow on Instagram, and he posted this thing about, it was just this joke. It was someone he was making fun of. He was like, "Who is going to pay for kids free lunch? Who's going to pay for kids free lunch?" He was like, "Me. I will pay for kids free lunch," because I think the issue is when people are arguing about, ""Why do my taxes have to be taken for your mistake? It was kind of reassuring to see that that's not the majoritarian narrative. There are a lot of people who are like, "Actually, no. This is important. We should pay for our kids' free lunch." As someone who is still a teenager, it was kind of scary for a second for a lot of people to be like, "Tim Waltz did something wrong." I was like, "What? That's crazy," so yeah, I think that was important. The last thing is, I know we're talking a lot about school lunches and things like that, which is important, but the other thing is I think child hunger and child poverty is such an issue in urban areas because of food deserts. I know in LA, a lot of people's closest grocery store is a liquor store. Some of my friends, I remember we wanted snacks, and so we would have to go walk to a liquor store nearby to grab snacks, and I was like, "That's crazy." I feel like that's also such an under, I don't want to say under-understood. I don't know what the word I'm looking for, I'm searching for right now, is part of the reason why we have so much food insecurity in the US.

28.words: I don't really know where to go with this, but I'm from South Dakota, we did not ever have free lunches for everybody. I just remember I was on the reduced lunches when I was younger, and I know that a lot of people talk about the stigma or whatever, like people are afraid to be on reduced lunches. I believe that we did have free lunches for everybody, but I do think that the argument about the stigma around free lunches or reduced lunches, it probably exists in some places, but I don't know. When I was a kid, people didn't know if you had free or reduced lunches. Those programs don't create a second class of lunch eaters. I don't know. I really don't know where I'm going with this, other than to say that even free and reduced lunches, people argue against those. I just don't understand how. I really don't, and I know [Zahad] explained the cons, but I don't want to get into one of those conversations, because I would get too angry and I don't understand the other side. I don't see any downsides.

30.words: I will say, when it comes to universal basic income, any remotely feasible plan would increase taxes on the rich by far more than whatever they gain by basic income, but I think, in general, so I think you said lack of empathy, and I think that's definitely part of the reason, but I think the other part of the reason is that lack of empathy, I think that means that a lot of, especially when it comes to American narratives around wealth and such, the idea is that if you're richer, you deserve it. You did something to get up to where you are. But the flip side of that, the natural flip side, the unavoidable flip side is that, if you are poor, then you have failed to do something or you've done something wrong and such. I mean, maybe from an outside perspective, you can say, "Okay, sure. I choose not to believe that," as something. I feel like I think most of us would choose not to believe that, but the issue then is that if you try and take that, if you do decide to take that and run with it, you kind of end up running into a lot of other foundational kind of assumptions about America and its economic system and such, which is why people, I think, are generally unwilling to do that.

35.words: I don't think it changed my thoughts, I think primarily because it didn't bring up much new information, other than the racial disparity, but it actually did make me think of something. Yesterday, I was helping my friends pick his classes. He's at UCLA orientation today, and they just started this new minor called food studies, and it's literally about this. The description is, "In the world, there are 1 billion people who are underfed, and then 1.5 billion people who are overweight. How did we mess up our food distribution this bad, and what can we do to fix it?" To me, I was like, "Oh. That sounds really interesting," but also, I think it's an indication that we are starting to, as a society, understand that this is a real issue like food distribution, and not like we never realized child poverty was an issue, but I think there's just more of a passion. 49.words: Actually, the reason I made that face is because it reminded me of an exact conversation I had like that. It was a college interview. I know, I know, I know. The interviewer asked me like, "Oh. What's a project you've been working on?" So I was telling them about my work with legal aid and helping people get resources to get their citizenship, and he kind of looks at me, and he is like, "Why?" I was like, "My parents needed their citizenship, and I have a lot of family that did, and it was really," Brianna's face, Brianna's face, and by the way, this was not a white man. This was someone who was very clearly second generation, and I was explaining to him why. He goes, "Yeah, but my parents did it." Again, this is a college interview. I was like, "This is not where we're supposed to be having this issue. I was just telling you about what I do in my free time." He was like, "No," and he's a doctor, by the way, who graduated from Georgetown. Yeah, it was Georgetown. He was like, "Well, my parents figured it out, and so I'm sure they did too. Your parents probably figured it out. They did it without programs like yours." I was like, "Yeah, barely. They barely did it, and they were pretty well off, all things considered, so let's consider the people that aren't well off." And so, it was the most conversation I had had about this, because I think, Jessie, you kind of hit the nail on the head. It's like people start with this empathy, and then they kind of do it, and there's slowly this ideological shift, where they're like, "Well, I did it by myself, so you should do it by yourself too." It's kind of like how people were so against student loan forgiveness, because they paid off their own student loans. I was like, "That's crazy." It's kind of like a sinking ship mentality, like take everyone down with me. I don't know. I think it's one of the most frustrating things about current American politics, where there's this very individualistic view of what a person should be able to do for themselves, but the issue is A, that's harming everyone else around them, and B, it's harming people who had no say in the decision, like kids who couldn't afford lunch, and they're also not supposed to be working full-time jobs. Why are we punishing them? I mean, I would go so far as to say, why are we punishing their parents too? But even on a base level, why are we punishing them? It's crazy to me. It's obscene. I don't understand it.
